description: Shamsud-Din Jabbar bypassed barriers to drive a rental truck into a crowd of New Year's celebrators on Bourbon Street in New Orleans, an attack that left 15 people dead and dozens more injured. The suspect, who reportedly made videos prior to the attack in which he claimed to have joined the Islamic extremist group ISIS, had an ISIS flag on his vehicle. He also had firearms, which he allegedly used to shoot at people as he drove through the crowd. Jabbar died in a shootout with law enforcement officers responding to the attack. Shortly afterwards police found explosive devices in the vicinity of the attack, possibly intended to target first responders. The FBI has said it believes Jabbar had accomplices; the investigation is still ongoing.

Following a tip from the suspect's family, law enforcement officers arrested Forrest Pemberton of Gainesville, Florida, following a traffic stop during which they allegedly found multiple firearms in his vehicle. Pemberton was subsequently charged by federal authorities with stalking with the intent to kill, injure, harass, intimidate or surveil. Authorities say he intended to travel to the south Florida offices of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, a pro-Israel advocacy group, with the intent of harming people there, possibly in a suicide attack. According to the Gainesville Police Department, Pemberton "often cited extreme rightwing neo-Nazi type statements and has shown anti-authority tendencies."

FBI agents arrested an Egyptian citizen and George Mason University student, Abdullah Ezzeldin Taha Mohamed Hassan, on a charge of demonstrating how to manufacture an explosive with intent to murder internationally protected persons. According to authorities, Hassan had praised Osama bin Laden and boasted of spreading Islamist propaganda online, including an ISIS (Islamist extremist group)-related video calling for the killing of Jews. Hassan also allegedly plotted his own mass-casualty attack, settling on targeting the Israeli consulate in New York City.

Timothy Bradford Cole II, according to authorities, an individual associated with a white supremacist gang, was charged with murder and other felony charges following a series of incidents that resulted in a deadly crash. Cole allegedly set fire to the home of a relative following a child custody dispute. A car chase ensued when police arrived on the scene; according to authorities, Cole crashed his vehicle into another vehicle, killing one of its occupants and seriously injuring two others.

An FBI sting operation following a tip about bombmaking resulted in the arrest of Harun Abdul-Malik Yener on charges related to an alleged plot to bomb the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE). According to authorities, in 2015 Yener considered going to Iraq to join the terrorist group ISIS, but he ultimately decided not to. In subsequent years, his interests gravitated towards far-right groups and movements, such as the Proud Boys and the anti-government boogaloo and militia movements. Yener allegedly told an FBI confidential source that he'd unsuccessfully attempted to join the Proud Boys and boogaloos, but they rejected him because he had wanted to pursue "martyrdom." The FBI used undercover agents to pose as members of a militia group to investigate his desire for a "reboot" or "revolution" in the country. Yener allegedly settled on the NYSE as a target because people would be sympathetic to an attack on it and it would "wake people up." Yener has been charged with attempted use of an explosive to damage or destroy a building used in interstate commerce.

In a sting operation, FBI agents arrested an accelerationist white supremacist, Skyler Philippi, charging him with attempting to use a weapon of mass destruction and attempting to destroy an energy facility. According to authorities, Philippi originally expressed interest to a confidential source in committing a mass shooting, then gravitated towards attacking the electrical grid. He allegedly planned to attach explosives to a drone and fly it into an electrical substation. However, the explosives had been provided by an undercover FBI agent and were inert. He was arrested while trying to launch the drone.

On October 26, Sidi Mohamed Abdallahi allegedly shot a Jewish man walking to his synagogue on a Saturday morning. When police and paramedics arrived on the scene shortly after the shooting, Abdallahi reportedly came out of an alleyway to open fire on them. Police returned fire, injuring and disabling the suspect, who was subsequently arrested. A door camera recording allegedly showed the shooter yelling "Allahu Akbar" as he began to shoot at police. The suspect was originally charged with six counts of attempted murder, seven counts of aggravated discharge of a firearm and aggravated battery. At the end of the month, local authorities also filed felony hate crime and terrorism charges against Abdallahi, saying that evidence from his phone indicated that the suspect planned the shooting and intentionally sought to target Jews. Abdallah committed suicide in his jail cell in December 2024.

Montana authorities arrested Daren Christopher Abbey, a self-described white supremacist with a prior hate crime conviction and multiple white supremacist tattoos, for the alleged murder of a man camping in a tent near Big Sky in southwestern Montana on October 10, 2024. He was charged with deliberate homicide and tampering with evidence. The motive for the killing is not clear. Abbey claimed self-defense, though he allegedly admitted to removing evidence from the crime scene and taking items belonging to the victim. Police say Abbey admitted to assaulting the victim with multiple items, including a screwdriver and an axe.

Federal authorities arrested Nasir Ahmad Tawhedi, an Afghan citizen, charging him with plotting a mass casualty attack in the U.S. on Election Day. Tawhedi had allegedly associated himself with the terrorist group ISIS-K. The arrest was part of a sting operation in which Tawhedi allegedly purchased two assault rifles and ammunition from an undercover informant. Prosecutors said that Tawhedi had an accomplice, a teenaged relative, whom they have not named. Another family member was subsequently arrested in France, charged there with plotting to conduct terror attacks in that country. Tawhedi has been charged with conspiring and attempting to provide material support to the Islamic State.

Prosecutors charged Nathanial James McGuire on numerous counts after he allegedly set off an improvised explosive device at a California courthouse. Six people suffered minor injuries. After the bombing, McGuire allegedly shouted that the government had taken his guns and people needed to rise up and rebel. In a video of his arrest posted to social media, McGuire allegedly called people traitors and told them not to violate the Constitution. When police searched his car, they reportedly discovered more firearms, another explosive device and ten Molotov cocktails. McGuire had previously been arrested in July after police allegedly seized a loaded concealed but unregistered handgun; he was scheduled to be arraigned on the day of the bombing. In October, federal prosecutors charged McGuire with using a weapon of mass destruction and other charges.

Ryan Wesley Routh was arrested by police following an incident at a golf course in south Florida in which he was apparently planning to shoot former president Donald Trump, who was playing golf on that course that day. Routh allegedly had a rifle and scope with him at the time. According to authorities, he left a note with a friend in which he acknowledged his intention to assassinate the former president. A former Trump supporter who had seemingly become disillusioned with the ex-president, Routh had views that were all over the political map. He spoke in favor of both Democratic and Republican politicians and in a 2023 self-published book claimed that he "refused to be put in a category" such as Democrat or Republican. Routh was a strong supporter of the war in Ukraine and had even tried to solicit volunteers to fight against the Russian invasion of that country. Online posts by Routh suggested that in recent years he had become anti-Trump.

On August 29, 2024, Corey Cobb-Bey, a sovereign citizen and Moorish Science Temple adherent, pulled his vehicle near a parked police cruiser, then got out and approached the officer sitting in the cruiser. After a brief discussion, Cobb-Bey pulled out a gun and shot the officer at point-blank range, killing him. Cobb-Bey removed a shotgun from the police cruiser, then waited for other officers to respond to the killing, engaging them in gunfire when they arrived and wounding two officers, one of whom was shot in the face and permanently blinded by her injuries. Cobb-Bey then fled in his own vehicle. After a 20-mile chase, he stopped, exiting his vehicle with a shotgun that he pointed at officers exiting their own vehicles; he died after multiple officers fired at him. Police have characterized the incident as an "ambush" and "execution."

In August 2024, federal authorities charged Hashem Younis Hashem Hnaihen, a Jordanian, with destruction of an energy facility and four counts of threatening to use explosives. According to prosecutors, Hnaihen sought to target businesses that he believed were supportive of Israel. Beginning in June 2024, he vandalized several businesses and facilities, including a propane gas distribution depot, leaving "warning letters" at the premises that included threats and demands. Hnaihen also allegedly attacked a solar power facility, causing more than $700,000 in damage. Hnaihen pleaded guilty in December 2024 to four counts of threatening to use explosives and one count of destruction of an energy facility.

On August 6, Zachary Babitz allegedly shot and killed an 83-year-old man outside a Best Buy store in Santa Fe, New Mexico. He then drove south in the victim's vehicle to Las Cruces, where he and a woman allegedly robbed a fast food restaurant and carjacked a vehicle. Babitz was subsequently apprehended. Babitz has a "1488" tattooed on his fingers and prior to the killing had recently become associated with the white supremacist Asatru Folk Assembly. Federal prosecutors charged Babitz with carjacking and related crimes. Initially, state prosecutors had charged Babitz as well but they dropped those charges in order to participate in the federal prosecution.

In an international terrorist incident, federal authorities arrested a Pakistani citizen, Asif Merchant, in connection with an alleged plot to conduct political assassinations in the United States. Merchant allegedly traveled to New York in April 2024 to hire hitmen to carry out the killings, but ended up paying a $5,000 advance to undercover law enforcement officers posing as potential assassins. Federal authorities say that Merchant had ties to Iran. He was charged with one count of murder for hire, but in September 2024 federal prosecutors filed a new indictment that also charged him with attempting to carry out an act of terrorism.

Deputies who responded to a disturbance call on August 2, 2024, were met with gunfire at the back door of a home. Two of the deputies were injured and a third killed. According to law enforcement, the suspects—two parents and two adult children—had stockpiled guns and ammunition, as well as food and supplies, and had anti-government propaganda and "conspiracy-theory media" inside the home. Statements made by the suspects also indicate they had religious beliefs. The sheriff's office said that the mother attempted to lure her neighbors, whom she believed were pedophiles, into a fatal ambush in the home, but when law enforcement arrived, she convinced them to enter the home instead. The father opened fire when the deputies entered. The mother, Julie Sulpizio, was arrested on suspicion of murder, attempted murder and other charges. Her husband, Michael Sulpizio, and two adult daughters, Savannah and Cheyenne Sulpizio, died inside the home, apparently killing themselves after the ambush.

In an international terrorist incident, federal authorities charged Michael Chkhikvishvili, a citizen of the nation of Georgia, with soliciting hate crimes and mass violence. He was arrested in Moldova to be extradited to the United States. Chkhikvishvili allegedly was an individual associated with the Maniac Murder Cult, one of several mostly-online and loosely-organized groups that combine elements of white supremacy, accelerationism, the occult and a penchant for demonstrative violence. According to authorities, he attempted to recruit others, including an undercover law enforcement officer, to commit a mass casualty attack in New York City. He also allegedly encouraged bombings, arsons and poisonings against Jews, racial minorities and homeless people.

The 18-year-old white supremacist allegedly taught an undercover law enforcement officer how to attack electrical substations in New Jersey. Takhistov, who had made arrangements to travel to Ukraine to fight with a far right combat group of Russian volunteers, also allegedly hoped to be able to bring back illegal materials from Ukraine in order to launch attacks in the United States. He reportedly said that his "ultimate dream" was to use a rocket to attack a synagogue.

On June 17, 2024, police arrested Casey Robert Goonan, a left-wing activist, charging him with the possession and use of destructive devices, multiple counts of arson and other charges in connection with a string of arsons and firebombings at UC Berkeley in June, including two separate incidents of firebombing police vehicles. After the arson of one police vehicle, an online post took credit for the attack that read: "In solidarity with our Palestinian siblings assaulted by the Zionist state in Rafah."

Police arrested Mack Adams Davis following an incident in which he fired shots at parked vehicles in his neighborhood. A subsequent investigation revealed that Davis had actually been plotting to commit mass shootings at a local Democratic Party headquarters and an LGBTQ+ bar because he associated both targets with the LGBTQ+ community and had accumulated an arsenal of weapons and ammunition with which to conduct the attacks. Police also found writings federal prosecutors later described as "indicating a support for Nazi ideology," including a notebook with a swastika and antisemitic statements, as well as anti-LGBTQ+ language. According to authorities, Davis frequently wrote about plans to conduct mass shootings against synagogues, mosques and other targets. In December 2024, Davis pleaded guilty to federal hate crimes charges, admitting he plotted to conduct an anti-LGBTQ+ mass killing.

Between 20-25 individuals associated with the white supremacist group Blood Tribe marched through parts of Deadwood and on the steps of the state capitol. Wearing red "Blood Tribe" shirts and black masks, a couple of marchers carried swastika flags and others unfurled a large swastika banner on the capitol steps. Blood Tribe leader Chris Polhaus claimed they were protesting the state's HB 1076, which covers the definition of antisemitism when investigating unfair or discriminatory practices. They were also demonstrating in recognition of the 57th anniversary of the mistaken attack on the USS Liberty by Israel, which is a conspiracy theory frequently promoted in propaganda materials by white supremacists and other antisemites to stir outrage against Jews and Israel.

Authorities in Oklahoma arrested five people—Tad Cullum, Tifany Adams, Cole Twombly, Cora Twombly and Paul Grice—in connection with the murder of two women from Kansas who disappeared while on their way to pick up the children of one of the women (the other was a court-appointed supervisor) for a party. The five people, who were charged with two counts of first-degree murder, two counts of kidnapping and conspiracy, were reportedly individuals associated with a loose religious and anti-government group called God's Misfits. At least one of the five, Paul Grice, was also a sovereign citizen based on documents he filed. The murders appear to have stemmed over a custody dispute.

The officers survived the attack, but law enforcement are investigating two deaths that may have been murders committed during the period when the fugitives were on the run.

Two individuals associated with the white supremacist prison gang Aryan Knights were charged with first-degree murder and other crimes for killings allegedly committed during an escape attempt. Nicholas Umphenour, one of the individuals, reportedly ambushed corrections officers returning the second individual, Skylar Meade, from a hospital visit, thus effectuating Meade's escape. Two corrections officers were injured. Authorities say that during their time at large, the escapees killed two men, one 83 years old and the other 72 years old, both on the same day. One man was apparently killed in order for the escapees to obtain a vehicle while the second man, a former acquaintance of one of the individuals associated with the group, was killed at his isolated residence. Authorities captured the men the following day.

In April 2024, federal authorities charged Kyle Benjamin Douglas Calvert with malicious use of an explosive and possession of an unregistered destructive device for allegedly setting off an improvised explosive in front of the office of the Alabama attorney general on February 24. On that same night, Calvert also allegedly placed stickers on state buildings that featured a variety of left-wing slogans, including one that read: "Support your local antifa"—stickers that he also reportedly displayed in a social media video. Calvert subsequently pleaded guilty to both charges and in November 2024 received a nine-year federal prison sentence.

They also shouted, “Deportation!” with the response, “Saves the nation!” The group eventually marched to the steps of the Nashville capital building where Blood Tribe leaders gave brief speeches.

Don Steven McDougal was arrested and charged with capital murder of an 11-year-old girl whose body was found in a river with a stone tied to it. McDougal, who lived on the property of the girl's father, has a lengthy criminal history, including a child enticement conviction, and was said by law enforcement to have ties to the Aryan Brotherhood of Texas. He has at least two swastika tattoos on his body.

Early on February 11, Kevin Colantonio set fires outside a predominantly Black church. Though the building was damaged, responders arrived quickly enough to prevent the church from being destroyed. Colantonio was subsequently arrested for the arson. Investigating officers found a notebook containing racist and extreme writings, including phrases such as "Gun down everyone that isn't white" and "Always give our bloodline a chance" as well as language about burning churches. In December 2024, Colantonio admitted to the crime, pleading guilty to several charges, including a federal hate crime charge.

description: Approximately 14 individuals associated with the white supremacist groups Alamo Active Club, Parker County Active Club, and White Lives Matter held a meetup at an undisclosed location in Texas. The event was a candlelight vigil to "show solidarity with the many White victims of brown violence."

Justin Mohn allegedly shot his father, then decapitated him, showing the severed head in an uploaded video in which Mohn ranted about a variety of right-wing topics ranging from antifa to the federal reserve, and issued a call for "patriots and militia" members to rise to violence. In 2023 Mohn had created a group he called Mohn's Militia, which apparently was a militia of one. He had also self-published a book called "America's Coming Bloody Revolution." Although Mohn's view were broad and not always coherent, he seemed to lean closer to anti-government extremist ideology than any other kind. Mohn was charged with first-degree murder and numerous other crimes.

Police charged Jesse James Sullivan, of Concord, New Hampshire, with the shooting death of his younger half-brother, Zackary Sullivan, on January 16, 2024. Jesse Sullivan was charged with second-degree murder and falsifying physical evidence. Zackary died of a single gunshot wound to the neck. Jesse Sullivan is a member of the Brothers of White Warriors, a New Hampshire-based white supremacist prison gang. Law enforcement have not yet suggested a motive for the shooting.
